expertSystem.title: Diagnosis of pediatric skin rashes.
expertSystem.description: A rash is a change of the skin which affects its color, appearance, or texture. It can be localized everywhere on the skin, even cover the whole body. There are many causes of rashes ranging from allergy, common diseases such as chickenpox, and anxiety to lead poisoning, genetic conditions and pregnancy. Methods of rash treatment are as numerous as their causes, therefore the diagnosis is the most important action the physician has to take and at the same time very difficult. The simple questions inside this file can lead to determining what kind of rash are we dealing with. The conclusions also suggest what disease can cause the rash. It speeds up the diagnosis by skipping the diseases that for sure can not trigger the occurrence of that specific rash.

question.content: Asses rash. Are there fluid filled lesions?
Vesiculobullous rash: Varicella zoster, Impetigo, Scaled skin syndrome, HSV, Eczema herpeticum, Erythema multiforme, SJS, Insect bites, Burns
Papular rash: Urticaria, Molluscum contagiosum, Scabies, Warts, Keratosis pilaris
Eczematous rash: Atopic eczema, Other dermatitis
Papulosquamous rash: Seborrhoeic dermatitis, Psoriasis, Tinea corporis, Pityriasis rosea
Erythematous rash: Erythema infectiosum, Roseola infantum, Other viral exanthems, Kawasaki disease, Cellulitis
Purpuric rash: Meningococcemia/septicemia, Henoch-Schonlein purpura, ITP, NAI, Trauma, Enterovirus, Leukemia
Blue or black rash: Hemangiomas, Vascular malformations
Hyperpigmented rash: Naevi – congenital and acquired
Hypopigmented rash: Pityriasisversicolor and alba, Vitiligo
